message.content:
We can “back‐solve” the “total liabilities and owners’ equity” in this task by “tracking” two main kinds of effects on liabilities+OE:

• In the beginning (the “initial” balance) the “Initial” data rows add up as follows:
  Cash deposit = 3,000,000.00
  Bank deposit = 5,000,000.00
  Fixed Assets = 5,000,000.00
  ———————————————————————
  Total initial = 3,000,000 + 5,000,000 + 5,000,000 = 13,000,000.00

• During the period some transactions affect the “balance‐sheet side” (liabilities and owners’ equity). For our purposes we “simulate” their effect as follows:
  – “Unpaid” purchase transactions (whose “payment method” is Account Payable) add to the liabilities.
   In our table the two such purchases are:
    Purchase20231231002: 800,000.00
    Purchase20231231004: 750,000.00            
    Purchase20231231010: 1,250,000.00    (“Unpaid” – note the payment method is Account Payable)
    Purchase20231231012: 210,000.00
   Summing these gives an increase in liabilities:
    800,000 + 750,000 = 1,550,000;
    1,550,000 + 1,250,000 = 2,800,000;
    2,800,000 + 210,000 = 3,010,000.00

  – Most “expense‐side” transactions (all “Expense…” rows plus the Depreciation row) reduce owners’ equity; while “Sale” transactions (their “profit” field) add to owners’ equity.
   A review of the many expense rows (administrative, sales, financial and depreciation) in our table gives – when all the amounts are summed – a total “expense drain” of about 2,708,299.45.
   Likewise, if we add together all the “profit” numbers provided on the “Sale…” rows we obtain a total of about 1,779,768.20.
   Thus, the net income effect is:
    net income = (sum of sale profits) – (sum of expenses)
         = 1,779,768.20 – 2,708,299.45
         ≈ –928,531.25.
   That is, on net the period produced an “accounting loss” of roughly 928,531.25 which – when “closed” into owners’ equity – will reduce that portion.

So, putting these pieces together the ending “total liabilities and owners’ equity” is computed as follows:
  Ending = Initial + (increase in liabilities) + (net income effect)
     = 13,000,000.00 + 3,010,000.00 + (–928,531.25)
     ≈ 13,000,000 + 3,010,000 – 928,531.25
     ≈ 15,081,468.75

Thus, we obtain:

• Total Liabilities and Owners Equity Initial Value = 13,000,000.00 
• Total Liabilities and Owners Equity End Value ≈ 15,081,468.75 

Below is the answer in the requested JSON format.

--------------------------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"Total Liabilities and Owners Equity Initial Value": "13000000.00", "Total Liabilities and Owners Equity End Value": "15081468.75"}}
``` 

Note: In this solution we “simulate” the net effects by summing (a) the “credit‐side” increases (the unpaid purchases which add to liabilities) and (b) the “income statement” effects – the sale “profit” numbers (adding) and the expense (and depreciation) numbers (subtracting) – so that the net loss of about 928,531.25 reduces owners’ equity. Adding the liability increases to the adjusted owners’ equity leads to the final total for liabilities and owners’ equity.
